argumentText: $\| x^2 \| = 2 \|x\|$ implies $\|x^n \| = n \|x\|$ for $n$ a power of two, while the triangle inequality gives $\| x^n \| \leq n \|x\|$ for all positive $n$ ; since any natural number is eventually upper bounded by a power of two, the triangle inequality again then gives $\| x^n \| = n \|x\|$ for all positive $n$. Finally, replacing $\|x\|$ with $\max( \|x\|, \|x^{-1} \|)$ gives the negative $n$ cases of the linear growth axiom.
